update.description:
This PR presents the initial implementation of the Feature System. ~~I'm labeling it a WIP because I still want to add some more concrete tests and examples for how features work, but the implementation is finished, and I think it's safe to begin reviewing.~~

Note that this is the **FeatureSystem_raw** branch. The old `FeatureSystem` branch was a prototype which is being discarded (although it played a big role in getting this branch to where it is).

I recommend looking at `Feature_TEST.cc` to get a quick high-level glimpse of what the Feature System is trying to achieve. There are three mock "features": `EngineMockFeature`, `LinkMockFeature`, and `SecondLinkMockFeature`. Each of these defines a function within a nested class (`Engine` or `Link`). We create a `FeatureList` which combines all these features, and then use `Engine3d` and `Link3d`  to extract and combine their APIs. As a result, `Link3d<MockList>` contains both of the functions defined in `LinkMockFeature` and `SecondLinkMockFeature`.

~~My next step will be to add more concrete and illustrative tests to `Feature_TEST.cc`.~~

To see a full-fledged test use of the Feature System, see `test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc`.
update.title: Feature System

update.title: Feature System

content.raw:
> I'm seeing lots of template parameters `typename Policy`, and I'm not sure what that means.

Your followup is correct: this refers to policy-based design. We might be able to come up with a better name for this template parameter than `Policy`, but I haven’t thought of a better name yet.

Currently, we use the `Policy` parameter class to tell the template whether it should be a 2D object or a 3D object, as well as whether it should use `double` or `float` precision. In the future, we could devise more policy properties which could affect the structure or behavior of features, but I haven't thought of any other potential properties yet. It's also possible for custom plugins to define their own policy properties and embed those into the `Policy` class.

> if you're just looking at the `Entity` class, it's hard to know what the `Policy` means.

Yeah, this is one of the biggest disadvantages of CRTP design \(second only to the craziness of C\+\+ template syntax\). Since the template implementations are recursive, it’s hard to start at one point and work your way up/down when trying to understand the code. Most likely, you’ll need to cycle through the code several times before fully grokking it.

The upside is, it’s an extremely powerful pattern which is highly maintainable because of the way concerns are separated. It’s just the initial attempt to understand it that requires a lot of legwork. Luckily, only maintainers need to do that legwork; users shouldn’t have to worry about those details.
content.html:
I'm seeing lots of template parameters typename Policy, and I'm not sure what that means.

Your followup is correct: this refers to policy-based design. We might be able to come up with a better name for this template parameter than Policy, but I haven’t thought of a better name yet.

Currently, we use the Policy parameter class to tell the template whether it should be a 2D object or a 3D object, as well as whether it should use double or float precision. In the future, we could devise more policy properties which could affect the structure or behavior of features, but I haven't thought of any other potential properties yet. It's also possible for custom plugins to define their own policy properties and embed those into the Policy class.

if you're just looking at the Entity class, it's hard to know what the Policy means.

Yeah, this is one of the biggest disadvantages of CRTP design (second only to the craziness of C++ template syntax). Since the template implementations are recursive, it’s hard to start at one point and work your way up/down when trying to understand the code. Most likely, you’ll need to cycle through the code several times before fully grokking it.

The upside is, it’s an extremely powerful pattern which is highly maintainable because of the way concerns are separated. It’s just the initial attempt to understand it that requires a lot of legwork. Luckily, only maintainers need to do that legwork; users shouldn’t have to worry about those details.

content.raw:
The implementation of the Feature System is essentially a mix of ECS, PIMPL, and Variadic CRTP patterns.

The `Identity` of an `Entity` is a crucial piece of the ECS aspect of the design. Every object must correctly know its `Identity` or else we can easily experience undefined behavior or segmentation faults.

I've put in a bunch of constraints to try to ensure that an `Entity` will never be given a bogus `Identity`. Specifically, I've made it so that only physics plugins themselves are able to produce `Identity` objects.

Nevertheless, implementation mistakes could be made, either within the feature system implementation or within a plugin implementation. To make those kinds of mistakes a little more obvious, the default construction of `Entity` and `Identity` will produce an `Identity::id` with a value of `INVALID_ENTITY_ID`, a.k.a. `std::numeric_limits<std::size_t>::max()`. If an `Identity` object ever has that value, we can immediately know that something went wrong during its construction, and if a user ever holds an `Entity` with an invalid `Identity`, then it most likely means that our implementation has a bug \(or the user is intentionally doing something that they’re not supposed to\).
content.html:
The implementation of the Feature System is essentially a mix of ECS, PIMPL, and Variadic CRTP patterns.

The Identity of an Entity is a crucial piece of the ECS aspect of the design. Every object must correctly know its Identity or else we can easily experience undefined behavior or segmentation faults.

I've put in a bunch of constraints to try to ensure that an Entity will never be given a bogus Identity. Specifically, I've made it so that only physics plugins themselves are able to produce Identity objects.

Nevertheless, implementation mistakes could be made, either within the feature system implementation or within a plugin implementation. To make those kinds of mistakes a little more obvious, the default construction of Entity and Identity will produce an Identity::id with a value of INVALID_ENTITY_ID, a.k.a. std::numeric_limits<std::size_t>::max(). If an Identity object ever has that value, we can immediately know that something went wrong during its construction, and if a user ever holds an Entity with an invalid Identity, then it most likely means that our implementation has a bug (or the user is intentionally doing something that they’re not supposed to).

content.raw:
Good catch! This is an outdated implementation from before the `Identity` class existed. Because of the weirdness of templates, this code won’t get compiled until the function gets used; that’s the only reason the compiler allowed it.

In [4d7d2e7](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/commits/4d7d2e7e19836ca748d97553a55f338664174d36?at=default) it’s been updated, and I added a test for each function. By having a test use each function, the functions get compiled, and we’ll see any compilation errors that might be in them.
content.html:
Good catch! This is an outdated implementation from before the Identity class existed. Because of the weirdness of templates, this code won’t get compiled until the function gets used; that’s the only reason the compiler allowed it.

In 4d7d2e7 it’s been updated, and I added a test for each function. By having a test use each function, the functions get compiled, and we’ll see any compilation errors that might be in them.

content.raw: this is a bit confusing to me, as `Entity` doesn't have a member variable named `id`. Since `Entity` is a friend of `Identity`, I'm guessing that the compiler is implicitly resolving this as `return this->identity.id;`?
content.html: this is a bit confusing to me, as Entity doesn't have a member variable named id. Since Entity is a friend of Identity, I'm guessing that the compiler is implicitly resolving this as return this->identity.id;?

content.raw: this line doesn't make sense to me
content.html: this line doesn't make sense to me

content.raw:
I'm not sure which order to read the code, so I've started with the base classes and am working my way up, and I'm seeing lots of template parameters `typename Policy`, and I'm not sure what that means. I see `typename Features`, and I think I know what that means, but we could expand the documentation about `Policy` somewhat.

Ok, I just saw some extra documentation in the FeaturePolicy class  about Policy-based design, so I can try to read that, but if you're just looking at the `Entity` class, it's hard to know what the `Policy` means.
content.html:
I'm not sure which order to read the code, so I've started with the base classes and am working my way up, and I'm seeing lots of template parameters typename Policy, and I'm not sure what that means. I see typename Features, and I think I know what that means, but we could expand the documentation about Policy somewhat.

Ok, I just saw some extra documentation in the FeaturePolicy class about Policy-based design, so I can try to read that, but if you're just looking at the Entity class, it's hard to know what the Policy means.

update.title: Feature System

content.raw:
I've removed the WIP tag because I'm satisfied with the implementation and tests (of course there could always be more testing, but I believe the critical concepts of the Feature System are being adequately tested now).

There are still two caveats for this PR:

1. One of the tests is using `Eigen` to show how a single "feature" can be used to construct an API for both 2D and 3D simulations (see `test/MockCenterOfMass`). `Eigen` is useful for this because the `Eigen` data structures can be templated on the dimensionality of the matrix/vector. This means that the tests currently depend on `Eigen`, and we need to use the current `default` branch of `ign-cmake`.

2. We need to use the `BetterPluginRegistration_DllManagement` branch of `ign-common`, because that's where proper support for template interfaces is introduced. I'll look into getting the `ign-plugin` repo into serviceable shape to be used by `ign-physics`, but my time available for ignition work this week might be somewhat limited.
content.html:
I've removed the WIP tag because I'm satisfied with the implementation and tests (of course there could always be more testing, but I believe the critical concepts of the Feature System are being adequately tested now).

There are still two caveats for this PR:

  1. One of the tests is using Eigen to show how a single "feature" can be used to construct an API for both 2D and 3D simulations (see test/MockCenterOfMass). Eigen is useful for this because the Eigen data structures can be templated on the dimensionality of the matrix/vector. This means that the tests currently depend on Eigen, and we need to use the current default branch of ign-cmake.

  2. We need to use the BetterPluginRegistration_DllManagement branch of ign-common, because that's where proper support for template interfaces is introduced. I'll look into getting the ign-plugin repo into serviceable shape to be used by ign-physics, but my time available for ignition work this week might be somewhat limited.

content.raw:
I also need to mention that this PR now requires the `BetterPluginRegistration_DllManagement` branch of `ign-common`.

At some point we should transition it to use `ign-plugin` instead of `ign-common`, but there's still a lot of cleanup to do in `ign-plugin`.
content.html:
I also need to mention that this PR now requires the BetterPluginRegistration_DllManagement branch of ign-common.

At some point we should transition it to use ign-plugin instead of ign-common, but there's still a lot of cleanup to do in ign-plugin.

content.raw:
I just introduced a major restructuring of the implementation to make the concept work for plugins.

I've also added an integration test that uses a mock plugin that provides a mock feature. The test can be found in `test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc`, and the mock plugin implementation can be found in `test/plugins/mock.cc`.

Right now the test only has the plugin implementing one feature, so I think the next step should be to add (at least) one more feature to it. Next week, I might have to shift gears towards SOSS work, since we have some hard deadlines coming up, but I may be able to add to the test this weekend.
content.html:
I just introduced a major restructuring of the implementation to make the concept work for plugins.

I've also added an integration test that uses a mock plugin that provides a mock feature. The test can be found in test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc, and the mock plugin implementation can be found in test/plugins/mock.cc.

Right now the test only has the plugin implementing one feature, so I think the next step should be to add (at least) one more feature to it. Next week, I might have to shift gears towards SOSS work, since we have some hard deadlines coming up, but I may be able to add to the test this weekend.

This PR presents the initial implementation of the Feature System. I'm labeling it a WIP because I still want to add some more concrete tests and examples for how features work, but the implementation is finished, and I think it's safe to begin reviewing.

Note that this is the **FeatureSystem_raw** branch. The old `FeatureSystem` branch was a prototype which is being discarded (although it played a big role in getting this branch to where it is).

I recommend looking at `Feature_TEST.cc` to get a quick high-level glimpse of what the Feature System is trying to achieve. There are three mock "features": `EngineMockFeature`, `LinkMockFeature`, and `SecondLinkMockFeature`. Each of these defines a function within a nested class (`Engine` or `Link`). We create a `FeatureList` which combines all these features, and then use `Engine3d` and `Link3d`  to extract and combine their APIs. As a result, `Link3d<MockList>` contains both of the functions defined in `LinkMockFeature` and `SecondLinkMockFeature`.

My next step will be to add more concrete and illustrative tests to `Feature_TEST.cc`.

content.raw: I'm guessing the list of feature types in `Feature.hh` is not intended to be exhaustive at this point, so we shouldn't try to add in everything right now, but I wonder if we will want to list supported shape types as `Collision` features?

content.raw: I made a small change to the FeatureList_conflict static assertion test in 03dab16 so it was easier to see how useful the compilation error message would be (since `Conflict` is already used as a template parameter in our code, I changed it to `Conflicted` in the test)
content.html: I made a small change to the FeatureList_conflict static assertion test in 03dab16 so it was easier to see how useful the compilation error message would be (since Conflict is already used as a template parameter in our code, I changed it to Conflicted in the test)

update.title: [WIP] Feature System

update.description:
This PR presents the initial implementation of the Feature System. I'm labeling it a WIP because I still want to add some more concrete tests and examples for how features work, but the implementation is finished, and I think it's safe to begin reviewing.

Note that this is the **FeatureSystem_raw** branch. The old `FeatureSystem` branch was a prototype which is being discarded (although it played a big role in getting this branch to where it is).

I recommend looking at `Feature_TEST.cc` to get a quick high-level glimpse of what the Feature System is trying to achieve. There are three mock "features": `EngineMockFeature`, `LinkMockFeature`, and `SecondLinkMockFeature`. Each of these defines a function within a nested class (`Engine` or `Link`). We create a `FeatureList` which combines all these features, and then use `Engine3d` and `Link3d`  to extract and combine their APIs. As a result, `Link3d<MockList>` contains both of the functions defined in `LinkMockFeature` and `SecondLinkMockFeature`.

My next step will be to add more concrete and illustrative tests to `Feature_TEST.cc`.
update.title: [WIP] Feature System
